snippet.textDisplay: Looks great, the 'reliability' of the data in the graph can be improved by plotting the number of deaths in a similar manner. The advantage of this is, deaths are more reliably reported, as these are almost all tested. The obvious drawback to this is that you are looking back in time even further. It could however be used to cross check the data, or even give a somewhat reliable estimate of the number of actual cases in a country (~ 2 or maybe 3 weeks ago), given that you multiply by a reliable mortality rate (might i suggest south koreas?). Of course this last bit only works as long as a country's medical system is not overworked.
snippet.textOriginal: Looks great, the 'reliability' of the data in the graph can be improved by plotting the number of deaths in a similar manner. The advantage of this is, deaths are more reliably reported, as these are almost all tested. The obvious drawback to this is that you are looking back in time even further. It could however be used to cross check the data, or even give a somewhat reliable estimate of the number of actual cases in a country (~ 2 or maybe 3 weeks ago), given that you multiply by a reliable mortality rate (might i suggest south koreas?). Of course this last bit only works as long as a country's medical system is not overworked.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is is the best representation that I've seen, it both linearizes the trend (so we can understand it) as well as smoothes it by averaging changes in cases over several days. The only thing they could do better (IMHO) is normalize it cases/million(population) vs. change in cases/million(population), this would enable a better comparison between countries.
To get a better understanding of why this is important, compare the # of cases in US (257,379) vs. China(81,620) - April 3, 2020.
Then compare the cases/million: US (778) vs. China(57) - April 3, 2020.
China has contained this so much better than we have.
Source: https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
It's a very nice web :) (seriously good job, thanks),

But there is still the question of telling how much is left if you are still in the exponential. As you notice, any of the countries that left the trend has far more recoveries+deaths than infections, and that always happend after reaching the peak (which occurs when the two magnitudes are equal), and that could be seen also in the time dependent graphs.

I think the usefulness of this representation is heuristic and it doesn't tell much more than a regular logarithmic graph of the active cases.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Henry and Aatish, congratulations on the methodology. I use it daily to track my country's and state's situation. Just a side note: the logarithmic scale is good to compare different countries, but it masks out the country's improvement, if there is any. Check Italy's case on linear and logarithmic scales to see the dramatic difference. The linear scale gives more hope!
snippet.textOriginal: Henry and Aatish, congratulations on the methodology. I use it daily to track my country's and state's situation. snippet.textDisplay:
1) The "assuming you trust the data" subtitle was an important note. Definitely worth questioning the reliability from more autocratic governments such as China and Iran.


2) This data seems to suggest a logistic curve looking at Total confirmed cases plotted against Time. It would be interesting to compare to Aatish's visualisation. It is true that time is not directly a factor in the number of new cases, but it provides insight into how government regulation early on can compare between countries (if an early benchmark in total cases is established to give all countries the same "start" on the graph.
snippet.textOriginal:
1) The "assuming you trust the data" subtitle was an important note. Definitely worth questioning the reliability from more autocratic governments such as China and Iran. 


2) This data seems to suggest a logistic curve looking at Total confirmed cases plotted against Time. It would be interesting to compare to Aatish's visualisation. It is true that time is not directly a factor in the number of new cases, but it provides insight into how government regulation early on can compare between countries (if an early benchmark in total cases is established to give all countries the same "start" on the graph.

snippet.textDisplay:
Noone talks about the fact, that China and Southkorea are naturally countries, where numbers (even though recently adjusted) are lower reported, even with influenca, etc.
So: Noone knows, if China and South Korea, based on their general system and traditionally too low reporting, this peak of others that report more correctly might last a little longer than we think.
STILL: Flatten the curve is a good idea, but doesnt solve the problem on how long it stays to beat the virus. Usually 60% of the population have to go through infection or infection rate needs to drop to below 1:1 ratio. There are still unknown factors, that might kick in and shortens it, but without a vaccine this is what we face....and the duration is the topic that interests most. In order to meet these numbers, we might have missed a point of total red alert in some countries and need harsher restriction further down the line, which noone can sustain. It really would have been better to fully lock down as properly as possible, but money and capitalism and living on the edge with your companies is preventing it. Money talks and that might have been a problem that some countries face for longer than neccessary.

America shows it. Even in times of normal influenca the backbone and security of the working population is so thin and the need to work is so urgent, that you see people with fever working as they cannot afford to report being ill for a couple of days. Such companies, I am sorry to say, are standing with one foot in the grave constantly and dont deserve to exist nontheless. Feeding them with loans just to safe employment is needed to be analysed case by case very carefully or we burn much more money and even fuel the fire of desaster with it.
A company with 100 employees in the industry or so...that exists for 10 years "successfully" should be able to survive a hard lockdown of 2 months easily, if neccessary. How can they say weeks into the crisis, that they all die out? What company has such thin backbones?
They already made use of turbo capitalism, the owner is a slaver and he probably used all loans and other opportunities to make number more compelling. Now, when the real numbers kick in, the company is lost? Sorry...dont believe it!!!
snippet.textOriginal:
Noone talks about the fact, that China and Southkorea are naturally countries, where numbers (even though recently adjusted) are lower reported, even with influenca, etc.
So: Noone knows, if China and South Korea, based on their general system and traditionally too low reporting, this peak of others that report more correctly might last a little longer than we think.
STILL: Flatten the curve is a good idea, but doesnt solve the problem on how long it stays to beat the virus. Usually 60% of the population have to go through infection or infection rate needs to drop to below 1:1 ratio. There are still unknown factors, that might kick in and shortens it, but without a vaccine this is what we face....and the duration is the topic that interests most. In order to meet these numbers, we might have missed a point of total red alert in some countries and need harsher restriction further down the line, which noone can sustain. It really would have been better to fully lock down as properly as possible, but money and capitalism and living on the edge with your companies is preventing it. Money talks and that might have been a problem that some countries face for longer than neccessary.

America shows it. Even in times of normal influenca the backbone and security of the working population is so thin and the need to work is so urgent, that you see people with fever working as they cannot afford to report being ill for a couple of days. Such companies, I am sorry to say, are standing with one foot in the grave constantly and dont deserve to exist nontheless. Feeding them with loans just to safe employment is needed to be analysed case by case very carefully or we burn much more money and even fuel the fire of desaster with it.
A company with 100 employees in the industry or so...that exists for 10 years "successfully" should be able to survive a hard lockdown of 2 months easily, if neccessary. How can they say weeks into the crisis, that they all die out? What company has such thin backbones?
They already made use of turbo capitalism, the owner is a slaver and he probably used all loans and other opportunities to make number more compelling. Now, when the real numbers kick in, the company is lost? Sorry...dont believe it!!!

A mere 4 weeks ago Americans were still laughing at China's horrible death toll and called it a "failure". "It'll never happen here because we are sooo much better, we're No. 1!" blablabla...

And now when US numbers and deaths are thru the roof, suddenly China's number becomes fake and too low? What's the logic here? Do Americans think they can get a free pass from coronavirus and wave it away because....they are Muricans? Does it make some people feel better believing more people died from the virus in China than in MAGALand? What a bunch of pathetic losers.

More people died in US because Trump admin did a terrible job at containing the virus, that's why. Stop making excuses, drop your ego and LEARN FROM CHINA. You arrogance is costing lives.

snippet.textDisplay: This graph and generally graphs in the news are deceiving as they don't take into account number of tests performed. By looking at this one you would say China has done a great job and stands near South Korea, and new cases stopped all of a sudden, but this should be reflected in testing numbers which would gradually go down. But that info is not available because this is how totalitarian regimes work, they only publish what looks good to them when for S Korea and Italy you can find detailed official data to probe numbers. South Korea is doing more than 1000 tests per day as we speak and getting around 100 positives and in China all positives disappeared when government decided to announce it 🤔

snippet.textDisplay: IF and only IF China doesn't lie about its cases, you gotta keep in mind that it is a communist country. Therefore, human rights are just a big joke. In democratic countries, this will stop only when we will have a vaccine. Thinking that in Italy, for example, there are only 100k cases is dumb. It is absolutely obvious that the number is way higher. BUT, keep in mind that mortality in march 2019 was higher in Italy than march 2020. At this point the number of deaths reveal just the intense spreading of the disease, not its mortality. The average age of people dying is 80 and 99% of them had comorbidities. Countries like Japan or South Korea succeeded in stopping the virus because they took the right measures really early. The rest of us gotta accept the situation and believe in herd immunity. The only way we could really stop this is by staying 1 month in the house and not leaving for ANYTHING. Like dying is forbidden. Food is forbidden. Water is forbidden. Everything is forbidden. Do you want to live in this kind of world, or take a risk of 1 in a million of dying from COVID 19 and live your life. BTW, last year 1.35 million people died in car accidents.
